citation.article-title: Saccharobacter fermentatus gen. nov., sp. nov., a new ethanol-producing bacterium.

p.s: Saccharobacter (Sac. cha. ro. bac'ter. L. n. saccharum, sugar; M. L. n. bacter, a rod; M. L. masc. n. Saccharobacter, a sugar rod)
Cells (Fig. 1) are small rods (0.5 to 0.9 by 1.0 to 1.9 μm) that occur singly and are gram negative, motile, peritrichously flagellated, and nonsporeforming.
No lipid granules are present in the cells.
Colonies on glucose-yeast extract agar are opaque and milky white.
Methyl red positive and Voges-Proskauer positive.
Strains ferment D-glucose with the production of ethanol, CO2, and small amounts of acids, but no hydrogen gas.
Strains convert 1 mol of D-glucose to approximately 2 mol of ethanol and 2 mol of CO2.
Glucose is presumably degraded by the Embden-Meyerhof-Parnas pathway.
The type species is Saccharobacter fermentatus sp. nov.
